title: Julian Assange extradition judge refuses request for delay
text:
Julian Assange has been told there can be no delay in his US extradition case, as he appeared before magistrates on Monday.

At a case management hearing at Westminster magistrates court, Assange’s legal team requested a longer period to submit evidence and claimed the charges against him were politically motivated.

After the defence and prosecution clashed over the timetabling of the case, the district judge Vanessa Baraitser refused to grant more time to gather evidence and told Assange his next case management hearing would take place on 19 December and there would be a full extradition hearing in February.

Earlier she asked Assange if he understood what was happening in court. “Not really. I can’t think properly,” he said. “I don’t understand how this is equitable. This superpower had 10 years to prepare for this case and I can’t access my writings. It’s very difficult where I am to do anything but these people have unlimited resources.

“They are saying journalists and whistleblowers are enemies of the people. They have unfair advantages dealing with documents. They [know] the interior of my life with my psychologist. They steal my children’s DNA. This is not equitable what is happening here.”

Mark Sommers, defending Assange, claimed the US had been spying on Assange. “This is part of an avowed war on whistleblowers to include investigative journalists and publishers,” Sommers said. “The American state has been actively engaged in intruding on privileged discussions between Mr Assange and his lawyer.”

Assange, 48, the founder of WikiLeaks, faces extradition to the US over allegations he conspired to break into a classified Pentagon computer. He faces 17 charges of spying and one of computer hacking, meaning he could face a 175-year sentence in a US jail if convicted.

In his third public appearance since his arrest in April, Assange wore a dark suit and a blue jumper and was clean-shaven. As he entered the dock, people in the public gallery raised their fists in solidarity with him.

The prosecutor James Lewis QC, representing the government, said he strongly opposed Assange being given more time to prepare evidence, pre-empting a request from Assange’s team.

Sommers said: “Being realistic, we need another three months.”

The proceedings in court went on while a protest outside organised by the Socialist Equality party took place, attended by dozens of activists chanting “Free Julian Assange” and “No extradition, there’s only one decision”.

Among those in the packed public gallery were the former London mayor Ken Livingstone and the journalist John Pilger.

Outside court there was a protest organised by the Socialist Equality party. Dozens of activists chanted “Free Julian Assange” and “No extradition, there’s only one decision”.

Assange last appeared in court in May when he was jailed for 50 weeks for skipping bail by going into hiding in the Ecuadorian embassy in London in 2012. He had done so to avoid extradition to Sweden, where he was wanted in connection with sexual offence allegations.

In his previous hearing at Westminster magistrates court, on 11 April, the day he was dragged out of the embassy by police after Ecuador revoked his political asylum, Assange was remanded in custody.

In June the then home secretary, Sajid Javid, signed an order allowing Assange to be extradited to the US over the allegations.

Information released by Wikileaks revealed the extent of state surveillance in western countries and the conduct of the US troops in the Middle East, which Assange alleged proved war crimes had been perpetrated.

The case was adjourned until 18 November for a “call over date” by videolink, since Assange must present himself every 28 days.

The final hearing in his extradition case is now due to take place on 25 February.
description: WikiLeaks founder’s legal team wanted an extra three months to submit evidence
